Dear Kari Ann Klinski:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention, prohibited restraints, elimination of restraints.
Description (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the
severity of the youth’s behavior, chronological and
developmental age, size, gender, physical condition, medical
condition, psychiatric condition, and personal history,
including any history of trauma, and must be done in a
manner consistent with the youth’s treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A alleged that Staff choked him after he was escorted in his
room.
Investigation I Spoke to Complainant 1 on 9/19/23. No new additional
information was provided.
I spoke to Administrator 1 on 9/19/23. Administrator 1 reported the
incident in question happened on 9/16/23 but was not given the
information until 9/18/23. Administrator 1 reported there were no
injuries to the youth in the escort. Administrator 1 reported the
nurse completed an assessment after the escort.
I spoke to DHHS Worker 1, scheduling and allegations were
discussed.
I reviewed the video of the incident.
The incident is dated 9/16/23. I watched video footage from two
different camera positions. Video footage was from 7:03:26pm-
7:15:57pm. Youth A and Youth B were in the pod with Staff 1.
Security 1 and Security 2 entered the pod and Youth A pushes
Security 1 into the door and then both Youth A and Youth B
attempted to grab things from their pockets. Staff 1 has left the
area. Youth A and Youth B begin pushing and shoving staff. Staff
1 comes back into the room and does not intervene, then
Supervisor 1 enters the pod and both Security 1 and Security 2
leave the pod. At 7:07:10 Youth A walks behind Supervisor 1 and
grabs or hits the back of his head. Supervisor 1 then turns around
and pushes Youth A up against the wall and holds him there.
Youth A does get released from this. At 7:09:00 Security 1 comes
back onto the pod. Security 1, Supervisor 1, and Security 3 are
engaged in a restraint with Youth B. Youth B is resisting and
fighting the restraint but is placed into the Primary Restraint
2

Technique (both staff have Youth B’s arms and are on one side of
the youth). They then transport Youth B into his room. Youth A is
still out on the pod. Youth A refuses to go into his room.
Supervisor 1 is attempting to talk to Youth A at the pod entrance.
Security 1, Security 3, and Supervisor 2 are standing nearby but
not engaged with Youth A. Supervisor 1 moves away from Youth
A. Then Security 1 and Security 3 attempt to place Youth A in a
Primary Restraint Technique. Youth A resists and Security 1,
Security 3 and Supervisor 2 hold Youth A’s back up against the
wall while holding onto his arms. Security 1 has Youth A’s right
arm held down with his left hand and his right elbow pressed
against Youth A’s chin to hold him. Youth A was held in this
position for 28 seconds. They transport Youth A into his room.
Youth A resisted the entire time. Security 3 and Security 1
remined in the room. There was no camera footage inside the
bedroom.
Interviews were conducted with DHHS Worker 1 at the facility
unless otherwise noted:
Supervisor 2:
Supervisor 2 reported he had entered the pod because staff had
called for “security” to come help. Supervisor 2 reported he knew
that Security 1 was the target of Youth A. Youth A reported to
Supervisor 2 that Security 1 made sexual comments about Youth
A’s grandma. Supervisor 2 reported that Youth A was name
calling Security 1 when he come into the pod but Security 1 was
not responding to this. Supervisor 2 reported they escorted Youth
A into his room and Security 1 and Security 3 were holding his
arms until into the room. Security 3 reported when they went into
the room, he left the entranceway of the bedroom for a minute to
find out more about the situation. When he returned to the door,
he heard Security 1 and Security 3 telling Youth A to sit down but
he was not listening to them. Supervisor 2 reported that Security 1
had blood on his shoulder. Supervisor 2 reported he asked
Security 1 what had happened, and Security 1 reported, “he bit
me.” At that point Supervisor 2 reported he asked Security 1 to
leave the room and he did so. Supervisor 2 took over after
Security 1 left. Supervisor 2 reported they were standing up in the
hold and he took over in that hold. They calmed Youth A down.
Supervisor 2 reported Youth A never reported to him that anyone
hurt him or choked him or punched him.
Youth A:
Youth A reported when Security 1 entered the pod, he and Youth
B attempted to “check their pockets” meaning to have them empty
3

their pockets and give them what they had. Youth A reported he
swung on Security 1. When asked why, Youth A reported, “this is
the one I wanted to get at.” Youth A reported that other staff were
present, and they started grabbing him and put him in his room.
Youth A reported he was resisting them while they moved him into
the room and once he was in the room. Youth A reported he was
face down on the ground and then on his back and they held his
arms down. Youth A reported he was able to kick someone and
then he bit Security 1 and then Security 1 started choking him.
Youth A reported no one stopped Security 1 from choking him.
Youth A would not provide any more details at this point.
Supervisor 1:
Supervisor 1 reported he received a radio call to come into the
pod. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A was attempting to “go through
security pockets.” Supervisor 1 reported that Youth A touched the
top of his head and they did a two-man restraint up against the
wall. Supervisor 1 reported that Youth A was swinging and
resisting the restraint. Supervisor 1 reported they moved him into
his room. Youth A was resisting the entire time to the room.
Supervisor 1 reported that Youth A was making threats towards
Security 1 and Security 3. Supervisor 1 reported that Youth A kept
saying that Security 1 had made comments about his
grandmother but was unable to vocalize what any comments
were. In the room, Youth A fell to the floor, but Security 1 and
Security 3 lifted him up and placed him on the bed, holding his
arms and then released him. Supervisor 1 reported that he never
saw anyone hit, punch or choke Youth A.
Security 1:
Security 1 reported he was completing security rounds with
Security 2. They went into the pod with Youth A and Youth B.
Security 1 reported he spoke to the youth and then as he was
leaving, Youth A and Youth B told Security 1 and Security 2 to,
“run your pockets.” “Run your pockets” is a phrase the youth are
using to tell staff to hand over everything in their (staff) pockets.
Security 1 and Security 2 refused to do so. Security 1 reported
Youth A and Youth B then attempted to put their hands into
Security 1 and Security 2 pants’ pockets. Both Security 1 and
Security 2 were able to leave the pod. Security 1 reported that
Youth A also said, “I’m going to smack the shit out of you.”
Security 1 reported he stayed out in the hallway and observed
what was going on in the unit. Security 1 reported that Supervisor
1 came into the pod and saw Youth A hit Supervisor 1 on top of
the head so he came back into the pod to help. Security 1 was not
asked to come back into the unit, but was not told to leave when
4

he reentered either. Security 1 reported they escorted Youth B
into his room first. Security 1 reported they didn’t have any issues
with getting him into his room. Security 1 reported they then
attempted to escort Youth A into his room and Youth A was
punching them and head butting them. Security 1 reported
Security 3 was able to get his arm hooked properly and they got
him into the room. Security 1 reported Youth A calmed down so
they let him go and then Youth A bit him. Security 1 reported he
said, “Is that what we are on?” Security 1 reported that Supervisor
2 asked him to leave the room and he did so. Security 1 reported
he never punched him or choked him or had him on the bed for a
restraint.
Security 2
Security 2 reported she was completing her rounds with Security 1
and they went into the pod. Youth B then said, “run their pockets.”
Security 2 reported she told Youth A and Youth B to “stand down.”
Security 2 reported that no one had made any comments about
Youth A’s grandmother. Security 2 left the pod and did not see
anything after this.
Security 3
Security 3 reported he received a call to go to the pod, so he did.
Security 3 reported Youth A and Youth B were attempting to go
into their pockets. Security 1 then went into the hallway. Security 3
saw Youth A grab the back of Supervisor 1’s head and was
instructed by Supervisor 1 to escort Youth A into his room. Youth
A refused to go into his room. Security 3 reported staff attempted
to get him into his room. Security 3 reported that Security 1 came
back into the pod and Youth A attempted to swing on him.
Security 3 reported that Security 1 and Supervisor 2 then helped
him with the escort Youth A was resisting, attempting to punch
and kick staff. When they went into the room, they tripped and fell
onto the ground and kept Youth A there. In the room, Security 3
reported he was holding down one of Youth A’s arms, as was
Security 1. Security 3 reported he did see Security 1’s arm on
Youth A’s chest and did tell him to ease up the arm. Security 3
reported Security 1 did respond and move his arm. Then Youth A
hit him and Security 1 stated, “bro what you want?” Security 3
reported Supervisor 2 told Security 1 to leave the room and he
did.
I reviewed the following documents:
Unusual Incident Report Summary: Date of Incident 9/16/23 at
7:05pm. Supervisor 1 write the report. The incident was noted
5

as a “resident assault on staff.” It noted, “…This writer, [and]
Supervisor 2, Security 3 and Security 4 arrived on the scene and
tried to verbally deescalate the situation but was unsuccessful.
Youth A and Youth B continued their assaultive behaviors and
were escorted to their rooms by Security 4, Security 3, and
Security 1. Both residents are scheduled to examined by the
facility nurse.”
Medial Assessment: Medical assessment was dated 9/18/23.
Youth A was seen in the pod. Assessment documents youth
states he was choked by “someone” in his bedroom. Assessment
notes superficial scratches on his neck and contact was made to
Administrator 1 to report to CPS. Order was completed for neck x-
ray.
Medical Assessment: Medical assessment was dated 9/19/23 in
the clinic. Youth reported, “security had him face down on the
ground and a knee to his upper back.” Youth reports neck pain. X-
rays were sent to the doctor.
Trident Care Imaging: Imaging assessed “no evidence of acute
fracture or malalignment. No significant degenerative changes
identified. Soft tissues are unremarkable.”
Handle with Care Manual: The one person and two-person
takedown method does not include using a wall to help assist with
the restraint. A two-person takedown, in step 7, show the youth is
dropped to their knee position, one staff in the Primary Restraint
Technique (PRT) and the other staff with his arms around the
knees of the youth bringing him to a sit-down position. The two-
person escort technique shows two staff facing the same direction
as the youth, one staff arm placed over the youths forearm and
the staffs hand placed on the upper back of the youth, while the
staffs other hand is holding the youth’s wrist.
I reviewed the SJJS Behavioral Management System,
behavioral Intervention techniques, Safe Physical
Intervention, and Use of Seclusion Rooms policy:
Definition: Physical Restraint: Touching the youth and
restricting his/her movement in any manner. Only an
approved SJJS technique may be used.
Safe Physical Intervention Techniques: all instances of
physical intervention must be reported to the immediate
supervisor and documented on the Unusual Incident Report
6

summary and the appropriate restraint, seclusion,
aggregate seclusion forms.
DHHS Worker 1 reported there was not a preponderance of
evidence for a confirmed case.
Analysis The restraint of Youth A was not completed in a safe and
appropriate manner.
• During the restraint of Youth, A, Security 1 had his right
elbow pressed up against Youth A’s chin to hold Youth A’s
head and restrict movement. Security 1 held this position
for 28 seconds.
• Youth A was restrained up against the wall and held there
throughout the restraint in the pod. Handle with Care does
not demonstrate restraints completed up against a wall.
• Security 3 reported that while in the bedroom Security 1
had his forearm on the chest of Youth A. Security 3
reported they had initially fell to the ground in the bedroom,
yet they both held Youth A’s arms down, outside of their
restraint module.
• Youth A had reported that he was attempting to go after
Security 1 by attempting to go into Security 1’s pockets and
told the staff involved that Security 1 had name called his
grandmother. Although the name calling was not true,
Security 1 was the target of Youth A’s assaultive behavior.
Security 1 had left the pod at one point due to being the
target of Youth A, but then came back in to assist with the
de-escalation and then restraint. Based on video footage
and interviews there were more than enough staff to
complete a Handle with Care restraint.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or
pushing a youth on any part of their body.

The incident is dated 9/16/23. I watched video footage from two

7:15:57pm. Youth A and Youth B were in the unit with Staff 1.
Security 1 and Security 2 entered the pod and Youth A pushes
Security 1 into the door and then both Youth A and Youth B
attempted to grab things from their pockets. Staff 1 has left the
area. Youth A and Youth B begin pushing and shoving staff. Staff
1 comes back into the room and does not intervene, then
Supervisor 1 enters the pod and both Security 1 and Security 2
leave the pod. At 7:07:10 Youth A walks behind Supervisor 1 and
grabs or hits the back of his head. Supervisor 1 then turns around
and pushes Youth A up against the wall and holds him there.
Youth A does get released from this.
Supervisor 1 reported that Youth A touched the top of his head,
and they did a two-man restraint up against the wall. Supervisor 1
reported that Youth A was swinging and resisting the restraint.
I reviewed the following documents:
Handle with Care Manual does not include pushing or holding
youth up against the wall as part of the Primary Restraint
Technique.
Supervisor 1’s personnel file was reviewed, and training has been
completed.
Analysis The video observation shows Supervisor 1 pushing Youth A up
against a wall. A two-man restraint was not completed as outlined
in the Handle with Care Manual.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff does not have the ability to perform tasks outlined in his job
description.
Investigation Staff 1:
Staff 1 reported that he needed to use the restroom. When
security came in, he went to use the restroom. When he came
back, the pod was in chaos. Staff 1 reported that Security 2 asked
for help, and he told her it wasn’t his job to help deescalate the
kids. Staff 1 reported it was the security officers’ jobs to do that
and they were the ones that escalated the kids, so he didn’t help.
Security 2:
Security 2 reported that Staff 1 left the area and did not help them.
I reviewed the Job Description for Youth Worker:
• This position is directly responsible for the daily
supervision, safety, security, welfare, and progress of the
residents in care.
• De-escalates emotional situations and performs individual
restraints and physical interventions as the situation
requires.
• Ability to act quickly and respond to all emergencies with
appropriate techniques, (e.g. de-escalation techniques,
safe physical management techniques, emergency
procedures, first aid, CPR, etc.)
Staff 1 has completed new hire training and was provided the job
description.
Analysis Staff 1 has been trained and has received his full job description.
Although he has been given these tools to perform his job, Staff 1
did not feel obligated to help provide for the security and safety of
the staff or youth on the pod.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention, prohibited restraints, elimination of restraints.
Description (1) A child caring institution, including private secure
juvenile justice facilities, shall establish a process
improvement and restraint reduction/elimination plan
that:
(a) Includes documentation of each restraint
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff did not complete and incident report, documenting a restraint
occurred for Youth A.
Investigation I reviewed the SJJS Behavioral Management System,
behavioral Intervention techniques, Safe Physical
Intervention, and Use of Seclusion Rooms policy:
Definition: Physical Restraint: Touching the youth and
restricting his/her movement in any manner. Only an
approved SJJS technique may be used.
Safe Physical Intervention Techniques: all instances of
physical intervention must be reported to the immediate
supervisor and documented on the Unusual Incident Report
summary and the appropriate restraint, seclusion,
aggregate seclusion forms.
Video observation for 9/16/23 shows Youth A was restrained.
Unusual Incident Report Summary: Date of Incident 9/16/23 at
7:05pm. Supervisor 1 write the report. The incident was noted
as a “resident assault on staff.” It notes, “…This writer, [and]
Supervisor 2, Security 3 and Security 4 arrived on the scene and
tried to verbally deescalate the situation but was unsuccessful.
Youth A and Youth B continued their assaultive behaviors and
were escorted to their rooms by Security 4, Security 3, and
Security 1. Both residents are scheduled to examined by the
facility nurse.”
Supervisor 1 reported he received a radio call to come into the
pod. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A was attempting to “go through
security pockets.” Supervisor 1 reported that Youth A touched the
top of his head, and they did a two-man restraint up against the
wall. Supervisor 1 reported that Youth A was swinging and
resisting the restraint.
10

Security 1 reported they escorted Youth B into his room first.
Security 3 saw Youth A grab the back of Supervisor 1’s head and
then was instructed by Supervisor 1 to escort Youth A into his
room. Security 3 reported that Security 1 and Supervisor 2 were
helping with the escort, and he stepped in as well.
Analysis Youth A was restrained on 9/16/23. An Incident report was written
but it did not note that Youth A was restrained. The incident was
written up as a “youth assault on staff.”
Technical Assistance: The word “escort” was used in the
incident report and stated by Supervisor 1, Security 1, and
Security 3 and Administrator 1 in interviews. Based on interviews
and video observation the facility is using the term “escort” in lieu
of restraint. Acts 116 722.112b (h) defines “physical restraint” as
the application of physical force without the use of a device, for
the purpose of restraining the free movement of a minor child’s
body. Personal restraint does not include: (iii) Holding a minor’s
child’s hand, wrist, shoulder, or arm to safely escort him or her
from 1 area to another.
The agency will need to retrain all staff and update policies to
reflect the correct definitions are being used and applied when
determining the difference between an “escort” (voluntary escort
with no physical force applied by staff or restraining the free
movement of the youth) and a restraint (application of physical
force and restraining the free movement of youth).
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
